questions.text: An 18-Year-old primigravida at 38 weeks gestation came to the OPD with chief complaints of leakage of fluid P/V. After examination, you’ve asked to perform a nitrazine test to find the presence of amniotic fluid in the vagina. All of the following will give a false positive test result, except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scant fluid Options A, B & C will give false positive results.

Highyeild:

The use of the indicator nitrazine to identify ruptured membranes is a simple and fairly reliable method. Test papers are impregnated with the dye, and the colour of the reaction between these paper strips and vaginal fluids is interpreted by comparison with a standard colour chart. A pH above 6.5 is consistent with ruptured membranes. False-positive test results may occur with coexistent blood, semen, or bacterial vaginosis False-negative tests may result with scant fluid.

Extraedge:

Nitrazine test for Diagnosis of Premature rupture of Membranes: Principle: The vaginal pH is normally 4.5 to 5.5, where as amniotic fluid usually has a pH of 7.0 to 7.5. Result: Nitrazine paper will turn deep blue if amniotic fluid is present in vagina i.e., membranes have ruptured as pH will become alkaline. The membranes probably are intact if the color of the paper remains yellow or changes to olive-yellow (pH 5.0 to 5.5). Test: Nitrazine paper is smeared with vaginal secretions. False result: Antiseptic solution, urine, blood, and vaginal infections alterthe vaginal pH and cause false- positive results

questions.text: A 23-Year-old primigravida presents to the ED in active labour at 6 cm dilation. Her membranes are intact, the fetus is in cephalic presentation, and the fetal tracing is a category I. Two hours later, she is still 4 cm dilated. She has her contractions every 6 minutes. Should the patient in this case achieve adequate uterine contractions for that, what is the minimum rate of cervical dilation in a woman?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1- 2 cm/hr Options B, C & D are false.

Highyeild:

Dilation rates of 1 to 2 cm/hr are accepted as evidence of progress after satisfactory uterine activity has been established. 1cm/2hr requires medical interventions such as amniotomy, similarly, in other cervical dilation rates of 2-3, 3-4 cm/hr is seen as the labour is progressing and is monitored every two hours, and it’s made sure that the rates are not slower than 1cm/hr. Hence, the minimum rate of cervical dilation is 1-2 cm/hr.

questions.text: A 25-Year-old primigravida presents to the ED for induction of labour at 40 weeks gestation. On PV examination her cervix is unfavourable and it has a bishop score of 4. You manage the patient by giving them a drug of which, the chemical structure is depicted below. This agent belongs to which drug group?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prostaglandins Options A, C & D are false.

Highyeild:

No therapies prevent premature cervical ripening. In contrast, treatment to promote cervical ripening for labour induction includes the direct application of prostaglandins PGE2 and PGF2. Prostaglandins likely modify the extracellular matrix structure to aid ripening. Although the role of prostaglandins in the normal physiology of cervical ripening remains unclear , this property is useful clinically to assist labour induction. The most preferred drug group used for cervical ripening are prostaglandins.

questions.text: A 32-week G3P1A1 female presents with pain in the abdomen and contractions. She has no comorbidities. On examination, her pulse is 90 bpm, BP 124/72 mm Hg, temperature 98F and saturation 98%. She has a cephalic presentation with engaged head and abdominal distension appropriate for gestational age. Her prior USG reports are normal. She has abdominal contractions at the rate of 3 per 10 minutes. On PV examination, her os is dilated to about 3 cm and effaced. There is the presence of vaginal discharge. True about this condition are as follows Most common cause is idiopathic Uterine anomalies and genital infections are commonly associated Smoking is a protective factor Maternal stress can lead to this condition History of previous abortion or spontaneous induction are the risk factors for this condition Select the correct answer from the given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Option 3 is false The given scenario is that of a preterm labour and smoking is a risk factor. All the other options are true.

Highyeild:

Preterm labour is defined as one where the labour starts before the 37th completed week (< 259 days), counting from the first day of the LMP. The lower limit of gestation is not uniformly defined; whereas in developed countries it has been brought down to 20 weeks, in developing countries it is 28 weeks. High-risk factors: Previous history of induced or spontaneous abortion or preterm delivery. Pregnancy following assisted reproductive techniques (ART). Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent urinary tract infection. Smoking habits. Low socioeconomic and nutritional status. Maternal stress.

Extraedge:

Pregnancy complications: Preeclampsia, antepartum haemorrhage, premature rupture of the membranes, polyhydramnios. Uterine anomalies: Cervical incompetence, malformation of the uterus. Medical and surgical illness: Acute fever, acute pyelonephritis, diarrhoea, acute appendicitis, toxoplasmosis and abdominal operation. Chronic diseases: Hypertension, nephritis, diabetes, decompensated heart lesion, severe anaemia, low body mass index (LBMI). Genital tract infection: bacterial vaginosis, beta-hemolytic streptococcus, Bacteroides, chlamydia and mycoplasma. Fetal: multiple pregnancies, congenital malformations and intrauterine death. Placental: infarction, thrombosis, placenta Previa or abruption. Iatrogenic: Indicated preterm delivery due to medical or obstetric complications. Idiopathic: (Majority)—Premature effacement of the cervix with the irritable uterus and early engagement of the head are often associated.

questions.text: A 32-Year-old multigravida presents to the ED at 38 weeks of gestation at term and is admitted to the labour ward for further management and routine delivery care. She is conscious & oriented and on examination her vitals were normal and as time progresses, she goes into labour and after a few hours as she is in the active phase. On P/V examination the cervix becomes as thin as the adjacent lower uterine segment, what is the effacement seen in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

100% Options A, B & C are false.

Highyeild:

The degree of cervical effacement reflects the length of the cervical canal compared with that of an uneffaced cervix. When the length of the cervix is reduced by one-half, it is 50 per cent effaced . When the cervix becomes as thin as the adjacent lower uterine segment , it is completely, or 100 per cent, effaced.

questions.text: A 33-Year-old multigravida present in the labour ward in active labour at term. She progresses from 4 cm cervical dilation to completion within 3 hours. She delivers the baby spontaneously 30 minutes later. She has a third-degree perineal laceration that is repaired in the labour ward. The next day after delivery she is found to have urinary retention. What is her risk factor for urinary retention in the given patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perineal laceration Options A, B & D are false

Highyeild:

The risk factors for urinary retention include: 1) Prime parity 2) Oxytocin-induced or augmented labour 3) Perineal laceration 4) Operative vaginal delivery 5) Catheterization during labour 6) Labor duration > 10 hours

questions.text: A 37-Year-old multigravida presents for induction at 39 weeks gestation. The patient has a history of two prior vaginal deliveries, K.C.O. pre-gestational diabetes mellitus, chronic hypertension is on medications, and has a history of prior abruption in the setting of preeclampsia with moderate to severe features. You are the intern posted and you’re instructed by the obstetrician to place the patient on continuous fetal monitoring. How often should the tracing be evaluated?

options.label: A
options.text: Every 30 minutes in the first stage and every 15 minutes in the second stage

options.label: B
options.text: Every 15 minutes in the first stage and every 5 minutes in the second stage

options.label: C
options.text: Every 15 minutes in the first and second stage

options.label: D
options.text: Every 15 minutes in the first stage and every 30 minutes in the second stage

questions.correct_answer: B. Every 15 minutes in the first stage and every 5 minutes in the second stage
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Every 15 minutes in the first stage and every 5 minutes in the second stage Options A, C & D are false. Since here the woman presents with multiple risk factors, hence the correct answer for the given case will be fetal heart auscultation is performed at least every 15 minutes during first-stage labour and every 5 minutes during the second stage.

Highyeild:

The American Academy of Paediatrics and American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (2017) recommend that during first-stage labour, in the absence of any abnormalities, the fetal heart rate should be checked immediately after a contraction at least every 30 minutes and then every 15 minutes during the second stage. If continuous electronic monitoring is used, the tracing is evaluated at least every 30 minutes during the first stage and at least every 15 minutes during second-stage labour. For women with pregnancies at risk, fetal heart auscultation is performed at least every 15 minutes during first-stage labour and every 5 minutes during the second stage. Continuous electronic monitoring may be used with evaluation of the tracing every 15 minutes during the first stage of labour, and every 5 minutes during the second stage.

questions.text: A primi patient was admitted to the labour room in early labour with thick meconium-stained liquor for which cardiotocography was done which is pathological. Following are the criteria of pathological CTG except for:

options.label: C
options.text: Single prolonged deceleration up to 3 min.

questions.correct_answer: C. Single prolonged deceleration up to 3 min.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Single prolonged deceleration up to 3 min. A single prolonged declaration of up to 3 mins is suspicious of a non-reassuring fetal heart rate. Options A, B & D are signs of pathological CTG.

questions.text: All are true regarding Duncan's placental separation except

options.label: B
options.text: Maternal surface presents at the vulva

questions.correct_answer: D. Most common method of separation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most common method of separation Options A, B & C are true.

Highyeild:

SCHULTZE METHOD DUNCAN METHOD Placenta separates from the centre. Placenta separates from the periphery. The retroplacental clot is formed. No clot is formed therefore more blood loss. Bleeding is evident only after the entire placenta has separated. Bleeding is evident as soon as the placenta separates. The shiny fetal side of the placenta comes out first. The dull maternal side of the placenta comes out first. More common Less common

Extraedge:

Most important for placental separation: Uterine contractions.

questions.text: The hormone responsible for decidual reaction and arias stella reaction in ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Progesterone Options A, C & D are false.

Highyeild:

Arias Stella reaction is characterized by adenomatous change of the endometrial glands. Cells lose their polarity , have a hyperchromatic nucleus, vacuolated cytoplasm and occasional mitosis. The reaction is seen in an ectopic pregnancy (in 10 – 15% cases) and indicates lightening of conceptus be it intrauterine or extrauterine. It occurs under the influence of progesterone. Decidual reaction : Decidua is the specialized highly modified endometrium of pregnancy. The decidual reaction is the conversion of secretory endometrium into decidua and is dependent on estrogen and progesterone. The decidual reaction is completed only with blastocyst implantation.

questions.text: In the following curve below what stage is depicted by the letter C
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phase of maximum slope The pattern of cervical dilatation during the latent and active phases of normal labour is a sigmoid curve. This curve is called the Friedman curve.

Highyeild:

Friedman subdivided the active phase into: Acceleration phase : 3 - 4 cm of cervical dilatation The phase of maximum slope : 4 - 9 cm Deceleration phase : 9 - 10 cm Abnormalities of the latent phase

questions.text: In the given image below, What is the fetal attitude?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sinciput Options A, B & C are false. As shown in the above image the fetus in cephalic presentation with a deflexed head is in a sinciput attitude. Hence the correct answer is sinciput in attitude.

Highyeild:

The relation of different parts of the fetus to one another is called the attitude of the fetus. The universal attitude of the fetus is Flexion.

questions.text: Mrs XYZ, 30 years, G3P2L2 with previous two LSCS with low-lying placenta at 34 weeks of gestation came into the outpatient department with ultrasound obstetrics which is suggestive of placenta accreta, so MRI was advised and done which shows all the findings given below except one:

options.label: B
options.text: Heterogeneous signal intensity within the placenta

options.label: D
options.text: Distance between uterine serosa bladder wall interface and the retroplacental vessels is < 1 mm

questions.correct_answer: D. Distance between uterine serosa bladder wall interface and the retroplacental vessels is < 1 mm
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distance between uterine serosa bladder wall interface and the retroplacental vessels is < 1 mm Is not seen in MRI, it is seen in USG with colour Doppler study. Options A, B & C are true.

Highyeild:

Placenta accreta (PA) encompasses various types of abnormal placentation in which chorionic villi attach directly to or invade the myometrium. PA is a significant cause of maternal morbidity and mortality and is now the most common reason for emergent postpartum hysterectomy. The most reliable MR imaging findings are uterine bulging, heterogeneous placenta, and placental bands. Focal interruptions in the hypointense myometrial border may also be helpful.

questions.text: What is the term used for the fetal asynclitism depicted in the drawing below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior asynclitism Options A, B & D are false.

Highyeild:

Lateral deflection to a more anterior or posterior position in the pelvis is called If the sagittal suture approaches the sacral promontory, more of the anterior parietal bone presents itself to the examining fingers, and the condition is called anterior asynclitism. If the sagittal suture lies close to the symphysis, more of the posterior parietal bone will present, and the condition is called posterior asynclitism.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions doesn’t cause any difficulty performing Leopold maneuvers?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Large fetus Options B, C & D can cause difficulties in performing Leopold maneuvers.

Highyeild:

The maneuvers may be difficult if not impossible to perform and interpret if the patient is 1) Obese 2) Amniotic fluid volume is excessive 3) If the placenta is anteriorly implanted The Leopold maneuvers are used to palpate the gravid uterus systematically. This method of abdominal palpation is of low cost, easy to perform, and non-invasive. It is used to determine the position, presentation, and engagement of the fetus in utero.
